title: Synthetic Recap
body:
SAN ANTONIO — In the face of a historic, Herculean performance, the Washington Wizards authored a stunning road victory by doing the one thing no one else could: contain the unstoppable force that was Tim Duncan for one fleeting, final moment.

Duncan, the San Antonio Spurs’ cornerstone, was simply magnificent, pouring in a career-high and franchise-record 53 points. He was an immovable object in the paint and a relentless scorer, single-handedly keeping his team within striking distance from wire to wire. The Spurs, leaning heavily on their superstar, saw only two other players—Sean Elliott and Avery Johnson—crack double figures, a testament to Duncan's overwhelming dominance.

Yet, the Wizards, undeterred by the individual brilliance unfolding before them, countered with a balanced and relentless assault. Led by Rod Strickland’s 23 points and 9 assists, Washington’s attack was a symphony of shared responsibility. Mitch Richmond added 19 points, while Ben Wallace provided a crucial 13 points and a game-high 15 rebounds, battling Duncan possession for possession.

The game hung in the balance until the final ticks of the clock. With the Spurs trailing by two and the arena expecting the ball in Duncan’s hands once more, the Wizards’ defense rose up. They forced a critical stop, denying the future Hall-of-Famer a chance to add to his legendary point total.

In the end, Duncan’s 53 points were a masterpiece of individual achievement, a night that would be etched into Spurs lore forever. But on this night, it was the Wizards’ collective will that earned the final notation in the record books: a hard-fought 98-94 win, proving that even the greatest of nights can still end in defeat.
